Good morning. Thanks to everybody on the phone. Thanks for those that are joining us on the webcast as well. Welcome to the fourth quarter earnings results presentation. Hopefully, everyone's had a chance to review the earnings that we released. It's available on the Bank of America Investor Relations website.
And so before I turn the call over to Brian and Paul, let me remind you we may make some forward-looking statements. For further information on those, please refer to either our earnings release documents on our website or our SEC filings.
So with that, I'll turn it over to our CEO, Brian Moynihan.

headline: Bank of America Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lee, and good morning. Thanks all of you for joining us this morning to discuss our fourth quarter results.Before Paul and [indiscernible] take you to the details of the quarter, I just want to provide some overall context in our progress in
componenttext:
Thank you, Lee, and good morning. Thanks all of you for joining us this morning to discuss our fourth quarter results.
Before Paul and [indiscernible] take you to the details of the quarter, I just want to provide some overall context in our progress in 2015 and the opportunity and challenges ahead. As you know, for the fourth quarter, we reported $3.3 billion in earnings or $0.28 per diluted share. For 2015, we had net income of $15.9 billion. That's the highest net income we've had in a long time. Full year returned metrics were 74 basis points for ROA and 9% through return on tangible common equity.
During 2015, we continued to drive rate [Ph] lines of business forward. We felt -- we focused on driving responsive growth across all our businesses. And if you look at the annual earnings of the company and see how it [indiscernible], you can see how it came through. Our consumer and wealth management businesses serving mass-market customers all the way to the wealthiest Americans delivered $9.3 billion of net income this year.
Although our banking business, which provides services to small, medium and large companies around the world, it is $5.3 billion in net income this year. And our institutional investor clients, our markets business, with its market-leading research capabilities and top-tier platform across the globe delivered $3 billion in earnings after adjusting for DVA in a very challenging market.
What's clear in these earnings despite the gyrations of markets, especially at the end of the year last year, is annuity nature that we get from our franchise by driving customer and client flows. That's the power of the company, its balance and scope and its solid -- its strong customer base. And we aim to continue to improve it everyday for our clients and customers and our shareholders. These results reflect the work we've done over the past several years to develop a more straight forward, simplified operating model and focus on responsible growth.
As you can see on Slide 2, across a variety of measures, loan growth, business activity, capital, liquidity, credit losses and cost management, we've made meaningful progress and believe we're positioned for a variety of economic cycles. At the foundation of this is a strong capital and liquidity base. We added to our record liquidity levels in 2015, when we believed we are well positioned against the 2017 LCR requirements with total global excess liquidity sources now at over $500 billion. This amount represents nearly 1/4 of our balance sheet, and we have enough parent liquidity to last more than 3 years before we need to test the market refund [ph].
Now our liquidity levels were driven by strong growth in deposits this year, and we were able to put that fund into work to grow loans on an absolute basis for the first time in several years. Loan growth was all driven by organic activity, consistent with our risk posture.
Our tangible common equity of $162 billion is at record levels as well. We returned $4.5 billion to shareholders this year in common dividends and share repurchases. Our tangible book value per share improved 8% in the past 12 months to new high of $15.62. Our responsible lending focus also shows under -- in our underwriting results. Our net charge-offs were down to $4.3 billion this year, consistent with 2014, but much lower than previous years. 
Commercial charge-offs increased off a very low base, mostly from oil-related charge-offs, while consumer losses as a core have continued to improve. This reflects both the response to underwriting as we continue to improvement in our legacy portfolios.
And finally, we get with cost management side. And the heart of our work has been improving expenses, which you can see are down sequentially from last year, mostly on lower litigation costs, but also on improved LAS and other operating costs. And these have improved steadily across the last several years. We began new BAC in 2011 and completed in 2014. Since then, we have been using our simplified and improved initiatives to find savings of more than offset increased compliance, merit and other inflationary costs, but most importantly, the savings fund investments in our business, whether it's in technology, our sales force growth or other infrastructure costs.
As we move to Slide 3, we included a few examples of trends business activity in our consumer side of the house and wealth management side of the house. As you can see, we grew average deposits in Consumer Banking wealth management business to $50 billion or 7% comparing year-over-year fourth quarter periods. These deposits were up over $105 billion in core deposits since the end of 2012. This is strong organic growth. It's a result of hard work and improving the customer satisfaction in our franchise by making it easier for customers to do business with our bank and strong product management simplifying the product set. All this has been done where we've optimized our delivery network, reducing our financial centers, divesting certain markets and also expanding our award-winning mobile capabilities in the customer base that uses that. As you can see, this work also extends to our wealth management business. We had long-term net flows for every quarter for 6.5 years in wealth management. We have record low levels and significant higher deposit levels. Good products and [indiscernible] are growing sales force into the leading brands and business divisions as well here.
When you move to our Global Banking markets area, you can see in the institutional side of the house laid -- setup forth on Slide 4, we saw solid activity in '15. Loans to commercial and corporate clients around the globe have grown nicely. Client demand has been good and our bankers have met our challenge to capture market share response. This focus allowed us to demonstrate a strong 12% growth in loans in Global Banking in the past 12 months. And you can see the deposit growth has been strong here over the last year as well.
If you look at the markets business, Tom Montag and team have done a good job reducing assets and lower the risk and still generating relatively stable revenue. Despite the recent market challenge, we remain quite profitable in this business and well positioned around the globe above the strong FICC and equity platform.
As we step back, we must remain focused on our core customer strategy. We will continue to invest in the future in the events we continue to address the legacy issues of the past. We've been able to grow even as the operating and economic environment remains in a low growth mode. Our model is solid, but there's still plenty work to do, but also there's plenty of opportunity ahead for us.
Overall, I'm pleased with the progress we've made in 2015, and we have more to do in 2016. But in 2016, you should expect us to continue to focus on responsible growth. We'll continue to drive the investments made in the franchise to deliver the value to the shareholders, we'll continue our sharp focus on risk management, and we'll continue our cost discipline as we look to continue to improve return on capital -- capital metrics of our company.
With that, let me hand it over to Paul.

headline: Bank of America Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Brian. Good morning, everyone. Starting on Slide 5, we present a summary of the income statement of returns for this quarter as well as the fourth quarter of last year which had similar seasonal aspects. We earned $3.3 billion in the quarter compa
componenttext:
Thanks, Brian. Good morning, everyone. Starting on Slide 5, we present a summary of the income statement of returns for this quarter as well as the fourth quarter of last year which had similar seasonal aspects. We earned $3.3 billion in the quarter compared to earnings of $3.1 billion in 4Q '14. Earnings per diluted share this quarter were up $0.28, up 12% versus a year ago.
Results include 2 significant charges that were previously announced and impacted EPS by $0.06. First, we recorded a pretax charge of $612 million associated with trust preferred securities, which phased out of Tier 2 capital at the end of 2015. Second, we had a tax charge of $290 million associated with the U.K. tax changes that were enacted during the quarter. Lastly, we had a few other items that benefit EPS this quarter by $0.01 on a net basis. These included a net -- a negative net DVA impact in sales and trading, that was more than offset by positive impacts of market-related adjustments in net interest income and some more on tax benefits.
Revenue on an FTE basis was $19.8 billion this quarter, up 4% from Q4 '14. Expenses were $13.9 billion, approximately $300 million or 2% lower than a year ago, driven by good expense discipline across the company. We also provided returns on a few other metrics on this page. I would remind you that client activity and revenue in our Global Markets segment tend to be low or lowest in the fourth quarter, affecting returns and other statistics. Lastly, as many of you are aware, there was a recent accounting change that requires certain unrealized debit evaluation adjustments to be recorded directly to OCI rather than through the P&L. We early adopted this change effective as of the beginning of 2015. The slides and the supplemental earning materials that present 2015 results have been adjusted.
Turning to Slide 6 and focusing on the balance sheet. We grew deposits by $35 billion from Q3, and we used these increased deposits to fund responsible loan growth. In total, assets climbed $9 billion, as increases in loans and security balances of $30 billion were more than offset by reduction in trading-related assets and cash. Liquidity rose to just over $500 billion, a record level, and time to required funding remains over 3 years. Tangible common equity of $152 billion improved modestly from Q3 as earnings were offset by both the return of $1.3 billion in capital to common shareholders and negative OCI driven by security values. Tangible book value per share increased to $15.62, another new record high.
Turning to regulatory metrics, we began recording regulatory capital under the advanced approaches for the first time this quarter. And the CET1 transition ratio under Basel III ended the quarter at 10.2 and really has no comparable metric as transition ratios in prior periods were reported under the standardized approach with lower RWA levels.
On a fully phased-in basis, CET1 capital improved modestly to $154.1 billion. Under the advanced approaches, compared to Q3 '15 pro forma estimate, the CET1 ratio increased slightly to 9.8%. RWA was essentially flat as growth from commercial exposures was modest -- mostly offset by lower activity and balance sheet level in our Global Market segment. We also provide our capital metrics under the standardized approach. Here, our CET1 ratio was flat at 10.8%, with modest improvements in capital, offset by modest increase in RWA.
In terms of the supplementary leverage ratios, we estimate that as of 12/31, we continue to exceed U.S. rules applicable beginning in 2018 at both parent and bank.
Turning to Slide 7. We had strong loan and deposit growth this quarter. Reported loans on an end of period basis increased $15 billion from Q3. This is the third consecutive quarter of reported increases in total loan balances. We continue to see solid loan demand in our primary lending businesses, partially offset by a runoff in LAS and All Other. Excluding declines in LAS and All Other, [indiscernible] loans in our primary lending segments increased $22 billion from Q3. $8 billion of this increase was in consumer loans as GWIM increased mortgages and security-based lending. Consumer Banking also saw a good loan growth in mortgages as well as vehicle loans.
We also had some seasonal growth in credit card, partially offset by selling $1.7 billion of card receivables at the end of the quarter. Commercial loans grew $15 billion, spread across multiple industry goods.
Turning to deposits. On many basis, they've reached nearly $1.2 trillion this quarter, growing $78 billion or 7% from Q4 '14. Growth was solid across the franchise. Consumer led the way, growing 9% year-over-year, while both Global Banking and GWIM each grew at a 6% pace.
Turning to asset quality on Slide 8. While still strong, we did see net charge-offs increase modestly from recent levels. Total net charge-offs increased $212 million versus Q3, $144 million was from consumer items previously reserved for, and lower recoveries on the sale of NPL in the fourth quarter versus Q3. We also saw a $73 million increase in net charge-offs from our energy portfolio. Outside of these 2 areas, net charge-offs were stable compared to Q3.
Provision of $110 million in Q4 was relatively flat with Q3. Reserve releases in consumer real estate and credit cards were partially offset by reserve builds in commercial, which were driven by increases in criticized exposures as well as loan growth. Reserve releases, excluding the previously reserved items I mentioned earlier, were roughly $200 million.
On Slide 9, we provide credit quality data on our consumer portfolio. Net charge-offs increased $130 million -- $137 million. The 2 items of note that make up this increase were reserved for in prior periods and did not impact provision expense in the quarter. $119 million was a result of collateral valuation adjustment. In addition, we had some small charge-offs associated with our 2014 DoJ settlement. We expect to complete our commitments under this settlement in the first half of 2016.
Adjusting for these 2 items, consumer net charge-offs were relatively flat versus Q3. Delinquency levels and NPLs continued to decline, and reserve coverage remained strong.
Moving to the commercial side. On Slide 10, net charge-offs increased $75 million, primarily from losses in our energy portfolio. Outside of the energy portfolio, commercial losses remained very low. Given the focus on the impacts of low oil prices on companies in the energy sector, we want to spend a minute to describe our energy portfolio and provide some perspective.
The pie chart breaks down our $21 billion of utilized exposure to the energy sector. This represents a little more than 2% of our total loan balances. Within that $21 billion, $8.3 billion or less than 1% of total loans is loans to borrowers in 2 subsectors: exploration and production as well as oil field services. We consider these 2 subsectors to have significantly higher risk than the rest of the energy portfolio. Of our $8.3 billion utilized exposure to these 2 higher risk subsectors, $2.9 million [ph] has already been downgraded to criticized. So 35% of the higher risk subsectors has already been downgraded to reservable criticized exposure, thereby driving a portion of the reserves. And allowances for loan losses for the entire energy portfolio is approximately $500 million or 6% of the fund exposure of these 2 subsectors.
Companies in the vertically integrated subsector represent $5.8 billion of the energy portfolio. We believe this subsector has a better ability to withstand lower oil prices. Nearly 100% of the companies have a market capital of $10 billion or more for their sovereign loan. And the average company has a market cap greater than $60 billion. [indiscernible] the remaining exposure in refinance and marketing as well as other is also less dependent on oil prices.
As part of our standard risk management process, we stress test our credit portfolios, including our energy portfolio. Our stress analysis of the energy portfolio includes various sustained low oil prices over extended periods. As an example, if we have oil prices at $30 per barrel for 9 quarters, we estimate our potential losses on the energy portfolio would be roughly $700 million. In energy, and across our commercial sector, we continue to support clients while managing lending limits and actively engaging with stress borrowers.
Before moving from asset quality, I want to refocus on total provision spends and how one should think about it over the next couple of quarters. As we continue to assess and react to future changes in the energy sector, we could see lumpiness that could potentially drive provision expense over $900 million.
Turning to our net interest income on Slide 11. On an FTE basis, NII was $10 billion, increasing roughly $300 million from Q3. NII included a negative $612 million charge associated with 3 trust preferred securities. These securities were scheduled to be completely phased out of Tier 2 capital as of Jan 1 and about [ph] 7% to 8% coupons became expensive debt. NII also included $115 million of positive market-related adjustments to the amortization of bond premiums under FAS 91. NII, excluding market-related adjustments and the charge on the trust preferred, improved $188 million from Q3 to $10.5 billion. This improvement was driven by increased deposit balances, which we used to fund growth in loans and securities.
As we move into the first quarter, please note the following: first, we will have 1 less day of interest; second, recent changes by Congress will lower the amount of dividends we receive from the FRB by approximately $50 million a quarter. Having said that, if the forward curve is realized and if we have some modest deposit loan growth, we still expect to show some growth in NII in Q1 '16 relative to our adjusted NII of $10.5 billion.
With regard to asset sensitivity, at the end of the fourth quarter, our overall asset sensitivity decreased slightly as a result of increases in volume rates as well as security balances. As of 12/31, an instantaneous 100 basis point parallel increase in rate is estimated to increase NII by approximately $4.3 billion over the subsequent year. A little more than half of that improvement comes from the increases in short-end rates and a little less than 1/4 of the benefit comes from market-related adjustments.
Turning to expenses on Slide 12. Noninterest expense was $13.9 billion in Q4, $300 million lower than Q4 '14. This was driven by good expense discipline across the company. Litigation expenses were a little higher this quarter at $428 million, exhibiting some lumpiness as we work to resolve legacy issues. Keep in mind that annual litigation expense decreased from $16.4 billion in 2014 to $1.2 billion in 2015. Legacy asset servicing costs, excluding litigation, finished Q4 a little better than our target of $800 million. As we have said, our net goal is $500 million per quarter. Expenses, excluding litigation and LAS, were $12.6 billion and represents the fifth quarter out of the past 6 below $12.8 billion. We continue to look for ways to streamline and simplify how we do business. This is important because it allows us to invest in growth while maintaining relatively flat core expenses in a sluggish revenue environment. And importantly, this relative flatness continued even as we invested in additional sales professionals and improve technology.
Looking towards expenses in 2016, let me remind you, in the first quarter, we will record, as normal, approximately $1 billion in cost for retirement eligible incentives. In addition, the first quarter typically includes seasonality -- seasonally higher favorable taxes of roughly $300 million. And if we experience traditional rebound in Q1 sales and trading revenue, this would also increase incentives and other associated costs.
Turning to the business segments and starting with Consumer Banking on Slide 13. Consumer earned $1.8 billion, 9% greater than Q4 last year. These results reflect good operating leverage on increased customer activity. The segment generated a strong 25% return on allocated capital. Revenue of $7.8 billion was up modestly from Q4 '14. Net interest income benefited from higher deposit and loan levels. Noninterest income was down slightly from lower mortgage banking. The decline in Mortgage revenue reflects selling fewer nonperforming loans as we hold more on our balance sheet. In addition, there was the absence of $30 million in quarterly revenue from the Q3 sale of a small noncore appraisal business. 
Expenses declined 2% from Q4 '14 as the savings from reductions in financial centers and personnel more than offset our cost from investment in 3 [ph] sales specialists. The cost of operating a deposit franchise remains low at 177 basis points. Operating leverage was an improvement in the efficiency ratio to 56% as we continued to experience shifts in customer activity away from branches towards self-serve options.
Mobile banking users increased to 18.7 million, which is up 13% from Q4 '14, and deposit transactions from these devices now represent 15% of deposit transactions. 
Slide 14 presents consumers' progress across a number of customer activities. I would highlight activities in 3 areas, loans, deposits and brokerage assets, where we continued to grow responsibly. These 3 products are the core of our rewards program, where we share benefits with customers who deepen relationships with us. Average loans grew $12 billion from Q4 '14 in mortgages and vehicle lending. And in deposits, growth was strong at $48 billion or 9% in Q4, while the rate paid declined to 4 basis points.
Regarding brokerage assets. Merrill Edge asset levels of $123 billion are up 8% from last year even with the declines in equity markets this year. 
Total mortgage production was up 13% from Q4 last year and stable with Q3. 
Looking at card activity, which includes GWIM, card issuance was strong at 1.3 million. Average U.S. card balances of $83 billion -- of $89 billion were down modestly from last year but up seasonally from Q3 '15.
U.S. cards' credit quality was strong as net charge-offs remain at [indiscernible] low levels of 2.5% with a risk-adjusted margin of 9.4%. Credit spending volumes finished on a high note as Q4 spending was 5% higher than last year, allocate the -- what we believe to be total market spend levels. Debit spending was strong as well. For example, on Christmas Eve day, we saw record debit card spending of more than $1 billion. 
In our consumer segment, we expect technology adoption by customers to continue to be a cornerstone of not only improved customer satisfaction but also efficiency gains and operating leverage. The latest examples of this are around digital selling and appointment setting. Digital sales in the fourth quarter were up more than 31% from last year. Digital appointments reached more than 15,000 in the recent weeks. We expect these adopting trends to play an increasing role in future performance and customer satisfaction as we continue to advance online and mobile capabilities. 
Turning to Slide 15. Global Wealth and Investment Management produced earnings of $614 million. Results were down from Q4 last year, driven by lower transactional revenue and the impact of the market decline on asset management fees. Transactional revenue continues to be impacted by the shifting of activity from brokerage to managed relationships as well as market uncertainty.
NII benefited from solid loan growth and solid deposit growth but was offset by the company's ALM activities, leaving NII relatively flat with Q4 '14. Noninterest expense was modestly higher than the year-ago period. Investment in client-facing professionals continues, while lower revenue caused a decline in incentive compensation that was more than offset by amortization of stock awards issued in prior periods. Pretax margin was 21%, down from Q4 '14.
Beginning in the first quarter of 2016, we will benefit from lower expense resulting from the completion of amortizations related to advisory retention awards given at the time of the Merrill Lynch merger. 
Moving to Slide 16. Despite the volatility in market levels, we continue to see solid client activity, and we continue to invest in the business, growing wealth advisers 5% from Q4 last year. Long-term AUM flows were $7 billion and remained positive for the 26th consecutive quarter. Deposit flows were strong, growing end-of-balance -- growing end-of-period balances $15 billion from Q3. By the way, this may have been driven in part by client concerns with market volatility.
Loans continued to grow, improving 10% from last year. This is the 23rd consecutive quarter of average loan growth in this segment.
Turning to Slide 17. Global Banking earned $1.4 billion, down 9% from Q4 '14 but still generating a 16% return on allocated capital. The earnings decline from Q4 was driven by higher provision expense. Provision expense was up $264 million from Q4 last year, driven by higher energy-related charge-offs and reserve builds for loan growth and energy-related risks. Revenue increased modestly from Q4 '14 while expense declined modestly. 
Driven by higher loan balances, NII improved despite spread compression and the allocation of the company's ALM activities, including higher liquidity costs.  Noninterest income benefited from higher treasury services revenue, higher leasing revenue and a small gain from the sale of its foreclosed property, partially offset by lower IB fees.
Looking at trends on Slide 18 and comparing to Q4 '14, IB fees of $1.3 billion were down 17% as leveraged finance and equity issuance were partially offset by advisory fees that were at second highest level since the Merrill merger. From a market share perspective, we maintained our #3 global fee ranking. 
Looking at the balance sheet, loans on average were $320 billion, up 12% year-over-year. The growth was broad based across C&I, real estate and leasing. We continue to experience some spread compression, although it has moderated relative to a year ago.
Asset quality of new loans was consistent with the overall portfolio. On deposits, we saw good performance with average deposits increasing by $16 billion or 5% over Q4 '14. The mix of these deposits remained very good with less than 5% classified as 100% run-off balances.
Switching to Global Markets on Slide 19 and comparing to Q4 last year. We are pleased with the results here given challenging market conditions as the teams increased revenues while using lower asset levels and less VaR. Global Markets earned approximately $200 million. But we think when you consider results excluding DVA, on that basis, adjusted earnings were $308 million, which was relatively flat to Q4 '14 on a similarly adjusted basis.  Note that our net DVA loss this quarter was $198 million and compared to a loss of $626 million in Q4 '14, which included an initial FVA adjustment. Total revenue, excluding DVA, improved $313 million or 10% from the fourth quarter last year on improved FICC sales and trading. Outside of sales and trading, Global Markets' share of lower investment banking fees was offset by a gain on the sale of an equity investment. 
Noninterest expense increased 9%, in line with revenue improvement. 
Moving to trends on the next slide and focusing on components of our sales and trading performance. Sales and trading revenue of $2.6 billion, excluding net DVA, was up 11.5% from Q4 '14. Compared to Q4 last year, FICC sales and trading of $1.8 billion improved 20%, reflecting improvements across most products, notably in rates and credit-related products. Equity trading of $822 million declined 3%, reflecting lower client activity. Average traded -- trading-related asset levels were down 9% in Q4 '14 while VaR was down 14%. 
Turning to Legacy Assets and Servicing on Slide 21. This segment lost roughly $350 million, in line with the prior year. Focus areas here are mortgage banking income, the number of delinquent loans and expenses, all compared to Q4 '14. First, mortgage banking income, which improved slightly, was driven by 3 factors. Rep and warranty provisioning improved $237 million to a provision of $9 million this quarter. That favorability was offset by a decline in servicing fees of $108 million and use of service declined, as well as a decline in net MSR hedge performance of $152 million. Next, the number of first mortgage loans that we serviced that are 60 days delinquent, continued to decline and are now at 103,000 units. And last, the team did an excellent job lowering expenses. Excluding litigation, we achieved our goal of $800 million, moving costs down $309 million or 28%.
On Slide 22, we show All Other, which reported a loss of $289 million. This was an improvement of $86 million from Q4 '14. This loss was driven by the $612 million pretax charge associated with our trust preferred as well as the impact on the U.K. tax law changes.  This was partially offset by gains in debt security sales as well as reserve releases on consumer real estate loans booked in All Other. 
A comment or 2 on taxes before wrapping up. The company's effective tax rate for the quarter, excluding the U.K. tax charge, was 25%, reflecting reoccurring tax benefits plus a few small [indiscernible] benefits. We would expect the tax rate to be in the low 30s for 2016, excluding unusual items. 
Before closing, I want to cover our early adoption of DVA accounting in more detail. In January of this year, the Financial Accounting Standards Board issued an update to allow early adoption of a new rule regarding recognition of DVA on financial liabilities from changes in our own credit spreads. The update means that these types of debit valuation adjustments will now flow through OCI instead of the income statement. We believe this change makes our earnings comparisons more meaningful and easier to understand. Therefore, we adopted early. We restated all prior years -- we, excuse me, restated all periods this year per the FASB rules, and those numbers are contained in the supplemental package.  This had no impact on capital as it moved dollars between retained earnings and OCI, but it did impact revenue, earnings, taxes and EPS in the first 3 quarters of 2015. The changes reduced previously reported EPS by approximately $0.02 each in Q1, Q2 and Q3.  This accounting standard adoption did not impact DVA on derivatives, which continued to flow to trading account profits. 
Okay, let me conclude by offering a few takeaways. Although the U.S. economy is improving slowly, revenue growth remains challenging. This quarter, we continued our progress on those things we can control and drive. These include delivery for clients and customers within our risk framework and driving client and customer activity that will result in sustainable profits and returns.  Our results reflect this focus. We maintained a strong foundation of capital and liquidity. We grew loans, deposits and investment flows. We continued to invest in our franchise by adding sales professionals and improved technology. Our strength, global capability and experience allowed us to deliver for clients in a challenging market environment. And we did all this while closely managing expenses.
With that, we'll open it up to Q&A.

headline: Bank of America Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we feel good about the operating leverage we achieved in 2015. Now you can see that in -- with the revenue growth relative to the EPS growth. And I think we're looking to continue that trend. We got a little -- we had a little bit of a tailwind he
componenttext: I think we feel good about the operating leverage we achieved in 2015. Now you can see that in -- with the revenue growth relative to the EPS growth. And I think we're looking to continue that trend. We got a little -- we had a little bit of a tailwind here on rates. We're going to continue to manage expenses carefully. If you think about the consumer, those sub-prime, no long FICO scores, if you look at the coming on FICOs are higher than the portfolio still, which is almost hard to believe, the charge-offs, delinquencies. And both home equities delinquencies across the last 4 years has continue to come -- getting lower every year and this year was the lowest they've been, all the way back a long time in both the credit card and home equities. And if you look at the client structure in the U.S., a couple of things. One is, we're adding officers in the middle-market business, but they're going after our target clients. And this is not go find new industries, et cetera. So whether it's the way we lend in commercial real estate, which is down -- which is very high-end real estate developers, et cetera. The way we lend in middle-market is very strong. So if you look across its client selection in the middle-market business, it's been strong. But that's -- that we're seeing is things in our business banking, small business portfolio, we're actually starting to see growth there against sticky target credit risk, which is the first time in many years that we had to run off some stuff and came in through [indiscernible] Maryland and everything else that we're finally seeing nominal growth. And so I think it's client selection. We slowed down international. It's sort of -- we're always watching, and in fact, using your stress test to make sure you stay balanced. And if you look at us, we feel we're pretty balanced between the consumer and commercial sort of 50-50. componenttext: It's coming from both. But the reality is that the #1 issue they face in the wealth investment broker services revenue line is the decline in transactional revenue. componenttext: I think the one thing overall is that as you look at the question on exposure that we're also paying close attention to is it sort of a demand or a supply issue for oil prices. And if it's a supply issue, that affects these companies and related companies and demand from. But if it's a demand in the broadest context, our economies continue to slow down, and that's the broader concern. So we're looking at not only the impact in all the portfolios, thinking about who gets the benefits in our portfolio basis from low energy costs, which are serious benefits to the consumers and to companies that consume energy, versus those producing it. And so there's a balance here that we've got to think through. Right now, it's pretty isolated -- the energy companies, and even if you look at consumers who work for them and are bases by ZIP code and unemployment levels and stuff, we've seen relatively modest deterioration or none, and in the consumer side, people employed in these businesses. So I think as you think about it, the real question is going to come down to for '16 in terms of all our industries, are we in a demand-driven issue, i.e., a general economic issue, or if the United States is going to plug along. And if it does, then I think follow-up guidance is the right one. If you're in the supply, it's going to all be localized on these industries.

componenttext: The only other thing I would add is we still have some opportunities to optimize RWA from an advanced perspective. That's in 2 fundamental areas. There's always stuff you can do in markets and other areas, but on 2 fundamental areas. One is, the expenses RWA we got on the wholesale side when we exited parallel run, that's not a permanent thing, we need to work on our models, work with our regulators. And hopefully over time, we can make some improvements there. The other one is operational risk. We have $500 billion of RWA [indiscernible] some of the advanced approach. So again, that will take time, but that's another opportunity for us to lower RWA from an advanced perspective.

componenttext: So Mike, when you look at consumer benefits from the oil and gas, just to give simple things, if you look at our card base, in the fourth quarter of '15, the spending on debit-credit cards rose 4% from the fourth quarter of '14. Hopefully, everyone's had a chance to review the earnings that we released. It's available on the Bank of America Investor Relations website.

headline: Bank of America Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lee, and good morning. Thanks all of you for joining us this morning to discuss our fourth quarter results.Before Paul Donofrio take you through the details of the quarter, I just want to provide some overall context in our progress in 2015 a
componenttext:
Thank you, Lee, and good morning. Thanks all of you for joining us this morning to discuss our fourth quarter results.
Before Paul Donofrio take you through the details of the quarter, I just want to provide some overall context in our progress in 2015 and the opportunity and challenges ahead. As you know, for the fourth quarter, we reported $3.3 billion in earnings of $0.28 per diluted share. For 2015, we had net income of $15.9 billion. That's the highest net income we've had in a long time. Full year returned metrics were 74 basis points for ROA and 9% through return on tangible common equity.
During 2015, we continued to drive rate lines of business forward. We felt -- we focused on driving responsive growth across all our businesses. As you look at the annual earnings of the company and see how they fell, you can see how they came through. Our consumer and wealth management businesses serving mass-market customers all the way to the wealthiest Americans delivered $9.3 billion of net income this year.
Our global banking business, which provides services to small, medium and large companies around the world, produced $5.3 billion in net income this year. When our institutional investor clients, our markets business, with its market-leading research capabilities and top-tier platform across the globe delivered $3 billion in earnings after adjusting for DVA in a very challenging market.
What's clear in these earnings despite the gyrations of markets, especially at the end of the year last year, is annuity nature that we get from our franchise by driving customer and client flows. That's the power of the company, its balance and scope and its solid -- its strong customer base. And we aim to continue to improve it every day for our clients and customers and our shareholders. These results reflect the work we've done over the past several years to develop a more straightforward, simplified operating model and focus on responsible growth.
As you can see on Slide 2, across a variety of measures, loan growth, business activity, capital, liquidity, credit losses and cost management, we've made meaningful progress and believe we're positioned for a variety of economic cycles. At the foundation of this is a strong capital and liquidity base. We added to our record liquidity levels in 2015, when we believed we are well positioned against the 2017 LCR requirements with total global excess liquidity sources now at over $500 billion. This amount represents nearly 1/4 of our balance sheet, and we have enough parent liquidity to last more than 3 years before we need to test the market we're funding.
Now our liquidity levels were driven by strong growth in deposits this year, and we were able to put that fund into work to grow loans on an absolute basis for the first time in several years. Loan growth was all driven by organic activity, consistent with our risk posture.
Our tangible common equity of $162 billion is at record levels as well. We returned $4.5 billion to shareholders this year in common dividends and share repurchases. Our tangible book value per share improved 8% in the past 12 months to a new high of $15.62. Our responsible lending focus also shows under -- in our underwriting results. Our net charge-offs were down to $4.3 billion this year, consistent with 2014, but much lower than previous years. 
Commercial charge-offs increased off a very low base, mostly from oil-related charge-offs, while consumer losses as a core have continued to improve. This reflects both the response of underwriting as we continue to improvement in our legacy portfolios.
And finally, we get to the cost management side. At the heart of our work has been improving expenses, which you can see are down sequentially from last year, mostly on lower litigation costs, but also on improved LAS and other operating costs. And these have improved steadily across the last several years. We began new BAC in 2011 and completed in 2014. Since then, we have been using our simplified and improved initiatives to find savings of more than offset increased compliance, merit and other inflationary costs, but most importantly, the savings fund investments in our business, whether it's in technology, our sales force growth or other infrastructure costs.
As we move to Slide 3, we included a few examples of trends business activity in our consumer side of the house and wealth management side of the house. As you can see, we grew average deposits in Consumer Banking wealth management business to $52 billion or 7% comparing year-over-year fourth quarter periods. These deposits were up over $105 billion in core deposits since the end of 2012. This is strong organic growth. It's a result of hard work in improving the customer satisfaction in our franchise by making it easier for customers to do business with our bank and strong product management simplifying the product set. All this has been done where we've optimized our delivery network, reducing our financial centers, divesting certain markets and also expanding our award-winning mobile capabilities in the customer base that uses that. As you can see, this work also extends to our wealth management business. We had long-term net flows for every quarter for 6.5 years in wealth management. We have record low levels and significantly higher deposit levels. Good products and advice, a growing sales force and 2 of the leading brands in business position us well here.
When you move to our Global Banking markets area, you can see in the institutional side of the house laid -- setup forth on Slide 4, we saw solid activity in '15. Loans to commercial and corporate clients around the globe have grown nicely. Client demand has been good and our bankers have met our challenge to capture market share response. This focus allowed us to demonstrate a strong 12% growth in loans in Global Banking in the past 12 months. And you can see the deposit growth has been strong here over the last year as well.
If you look at the markets business, Tom Montag and the team have done a good job reducing assets and lower the risk and still generating relatively stable revenue. Despite the recent market challenge, we remain quite profitable in this business and well positioned around the globe with both a strong FICC and equity platform.
As we step back, we must remain focused on our core customer strategy. We will continue to invest in the future in the events we continue to address the legacy issues of the past. We've been able to grow even as the operating and economic environment remains in a low growth mode. Our model is solid, but there's still plenty work to do, but also there's plenty of opportunity ahead for us.
Overall, I'm pleased with the progress we've made in 2015, and we have more to do in 2016. But in 2016, you should expect us to continue to focus on responsible growth. We'll continue to drive the investments made in the franchise to deliver the value to you as shareholders, we'll continue our sharp focus on risk management, and we'll continue our cost discipline as we look to continue to improve return on capital -- capital metrics of our company.
With that, let me hand it over to Paul.

Thanks, Brian. Good morning, everyone. Starting on Slide 5, we present a summary of the income statement of returns for this quarter as well as the fourth quarter of last year which had similar seasonal aspects. We earned $3.3 billion in the quarter compared to earnings of $3.1 billion in 4Q '14. Earnings per diluted share this quarter were up $0.28, up 12% versus a year ago.
Results include 2 significant charges that were previously announced and impacted EPS by $0.06. First, we recorded a pretax charge of $612 million associated with trust preferred securities, which phased out of Tier 2 capital at the end of 2015. Second, we had a tax charge of $290 million associated with the U.K. tax changes that were enacted during the quarter. Lastly, we had a few other items that benefit EPS this quarter by $0.01 on a net basis. These included a net -- a negative net DVA impact in sales and trading that was more than offset by positive impacts of market-related adjustments in net interest income and some one-off tax benefits.
Revenue on an FTE basis was $19.8 billion this quarter, up 4% from Q4 '14. Expenses were $13.9 billion, approximately $300 million or 2% lower than a year ago, driven by good expense discipline across the company. We also provided returns on a few other metrics on this page. I would remind you that client activity and revenue in our Global Markets segment tend to be lower or lowest in the fourth quarter, affecting returns and other statistics. Lastly, as many of you are aware, there was a recent accounting change that requires certain unrealized debit evaluation adjustments to be recorded directly to OCI rather than through the P&L. We early adopted this change effective as of the beginning of 2015. The slides and the supplemental earning materials that present 2015 results have been adjusted.
Turning to Slide 6 and focusing on the balance sheet. We grew deposits by $35 billion from Q3, and we used these increased deposits to fund responsible loan growth. In total, assets climbed $9 billion, as increases in loans and security balances of $30 billion were more than offset by reduction in trading-related assets and cash. Liquidity rose to just over $500 billion, a record level, and time to required funding remains over 3 years. Tangible common equity of $162 billion improved modestly from Q3 as earnings were offset by both the return of $1.3 billion in capital to common shareholders and negative OCI driven by security values. Tangible book value per share increased to $15.62, another new record high.
Turning to regulatory metrics, we began recording regulatory capital under the advanced approaches for the first time this quarter. And the CET1 transition ratio under Basel III ended the quarter at 10.2 and really has no comparable metric as transition ratios in prior periods were reported under the standardized approach with lower RWA levels.
On a fully phased-in basis, CET1 capital improved modestly to $154.1 billion. Under the advanced approaches, compared to Q3 '15 pro forma estimate, the CET1 ratio increased slightly to 9.8%. RWA was essentially flat as growth from commercial exposures was modest -- mostly offset by lower activity and balance sheet level in our Global Market segment. We also provide our capital metrics under the standardized approach. Here, our CET1 ratio was flat at 10.8%, with modest improvements in capital, offset by modest increase in RWA.
In terms of the supplementary leverage ratios, we estimate that as of 12/31, we continue to exceed U.S. rules applicable beginning in 2018 at both parent and bank.
Turning to Slide 7. We had strong loan and deposit growth this quarter. Reported loans on an end of period basis increased $15 billion from Q3. This is the third consecutive quarter of reported increases in total loan balances. We continue to see solid loan demand in our primary lending businesses, partially offset by a runoff in LAS and All Other. Excluding declines in LAS and All Other, ending loans in our primary lending segments increased $22 billion from Q3. $8 billion of this increase was in consumer loans as GWIM increased mortgages and security-based lending. Consumer Banking also saw a good loan growth in mortgages as well as vehicle loans.
We also had some seasonal growth in credit card, partially offset by selling $1.7 billion of card receivables at the end of the quarter. Commercial loans grew $15 billion, spread across multiple industry groups.
Turning to deposits. On many basis, they've reached nearly $1.2 trillion this quarter, growing $78 billion or 7% from Q4 '14. Growth was solid across the franchise. Consumer led the way, growing 9% year-over-year, while both Global Banking and GWIM each grew at a 6% pace.
Turning to asset quality on Slide 8. While still strong, we did see net charge-offs increase modestly from recent levels. Total net charge-offs increased $212 million versus Q3, $144 million was from consumer items previously reserved for, and lower recoveries on the sale of NPL in the fourth quarter versus Q3. We also saw a $73 million increase in net charge-offs from our energy portfolio. Outside of these 2 areas, net charge-offs were stable compared to Q3.
Provision of $110 million in Q4 was relatively flat with Q3. Reserve releases in consumer real estate and credit cards were partially offset by reserve builds in commercial, which were driven by increases in criticized exposures as well as loan growth. Reserve releases, excluding the previously reserved items I mentioned earlier, were roughly $200 million.
On Slide 9, we provide credit quality data on our consumer portfolio. Net charge-offs increased $130 million -- $137 million. The 2 items of note that make up this increase were reserved for in prior periods and did not impact provision expense in the quarter. $119 million was a result of collateral valuation adjustment. In addition, we had some small charge-offs associated with our 2014 DoJ settlement. We expect to complete our commitments under this settlement in the first half of 2016.
Adjusting for these 2 items, consumer net charge-offs were relatively flat versus Q3. Delinquency levels and NPLs continue to decline, and reserve coverage remained strong.
Moving to the commercial side. On Slide 10, net charge-offs increased $75 million, primarily from losses in our energy portfolio. Outside of the energy portfolio, commercial losses remained very low. Given the focus on the impacts of low oil prices on companies in the energy sector, we want to spend a minute to describe our energy portfolio and provide some perspective.
The pie chart breaks down our $21 billion of utilized exposure to the energy sector. This represents a little more than 2% of our total loan balances. Within that $21 billion, $8.3 million or less than 1% of total loans is loans to borrowers in 2 subsectors: exploration and production as well as oil field services. We consider these 2 subsectors to have significantly higher risk than the rest of the energy portfolio. Of our $8.3 billion (sic [$8.3 million] utilized exposure to these 2 higher risk subsectors, $2.9 million has already been downgraded to criticized. So 35% of the higher risk subsectors has already been downgraded to reservable criticized exposure, thereby driving a portion of the reserves. And allowances for loan losses for the entire energy portfolio is approximately $500 million or 6% of the fund exposure of these 2 subsectors.
Companies in the vertically integrated subsector represent $5.8 billion of the energy portfolio. We believe this subsector has a better ability to withstand lower oil prices. Nearly 100% of the companies have a market capital of $10 billion or more for their sovereign loan. And the average company has a market cap greater than $60 billion. We believe the remaining exposure in refining and marketing as well as other is also less dependent on oil prices.
As part of our standard risk management process, we stress test our credit portfolios, including our energy portfolio. Our stress analysis of the energy portfolio includes various sustained low oil prices over extended periods. As an example, if we have oil prices at $30 per barrel for 9 quarters, we estimate our potential losses on the energy portfolio would be roughly $700 million. In energy, and across our commercial sector, we continue to support clients while managing lending limits and actively engaging with stress borrowers.
Before moving from asset quality, I want to refocus on total provision spends and how one should think about it over the next couple of quarters. As we continue to access and react to future changes in the energy sector, we could see lumpiness that could potentially drive provision expense over $900 million.
Turning to our net interest income on Slide 11. On an FTE basis, NII was $10 billion, increasing roughly $300 million from Q3. NII included a negative $612 million charge associated with 3 trust preferred securities. These securities were scheduled to be completely phased out of Tier 2 capital as of Jan 1 and with 7% to 8% coupons became expensive debt. NII also included $115 million of positive market-related adjustments to the amortization of bond premiums under FAS 91. NII, excluding market-related adjustments and the charge on the trust preferred, improved $188 million from Q3 to $10.5 billion. This improvement was driven by increased deposit balances, which we used to fund growth in loans and securities.
As we move into the first quarter, please note the following: first, we will have 1 less day of interest; second, recent changes by Congress will lower the amount of dividends we receive from the FRB by approximately $50 million a quarter. Having said that, if the forward curve is realized and if we have some modest deposit loan growth, we still expect to show some growth in NII in Q1 '16 relative to our adjusted NII of $10.5 billion.
With regard to asset sensitivity, at the end of the fourth quarter, our overall asset sensitivity decreased slightly as a result of increases in volume [ph] rates as well as security balances. As of 12/31, an instantaneous 100 basis point parallel increase in rates is estimated to increase NII by approximately $4.3 billion over the subsequent year. A little more than half of that improvement comes from the increases in short-end rates and a little less than 1/4 of the benefit comes from market-related adjustments.
Turning to expenses on Slide 12. Noninterest expense was $13.9 billion in Q4, $300 million lower than Q4 '14. This was driven by good expense discipline across the company. Litigation expenses were a little higher this quarter at $428 million, exhibiting some lumpiness as we work to resolve legacy issues. Keep in mind that annual litigation expense decreased from $16.4 billion in 2014 to $1.2 billion in 2015. Legacy asset servicing costs, excluding litigation, finished Q4 a little better than our target of $800 million. As we have said, our net goal is $500 million per quarter. Expenses, excluding litigation and LAS, were $12.6 billion and represents the fifth quarter out of the past 6 below $12.8 billion. We continue to look for ways to streamline and simplify how we do business. This is important because it allows us to invest in growth while maintaining relatively flat core expenses in a sluggish revenue environment. And importantly, this relative flatness continued even as we invested in additional sales professionals and improve technology.
Looking towards expenses in 2016, let me remind you, in the first quarter, we will record, as normal, approximately $1 billion in cost for retirement eligible incentives. In addition, the first quarter typically includes seasonality -- seasonally higher favorable taxes of roughly $300 million. And if we experience traditional rebound in Q1 sales and trading revenue, this would also increase incentives and other associated costs.
Turning to the business segments and starting with Consumer Banking on Slide 13. Consumer earned $1.8 billion, 9% greater than Q4 last year. These results reflect good operating leverage on increased customer activity. The segment generated a strong 25% return on allocated capital. Revenue of $7.8 billion was up modestly from Q4 '14. Net interest income benefited from higher deposit and loan levels. 
Noninterest income was down slightly from lower mortgage banking. The decline in Mortgage revenue reflects selling fewer nonperforming loans as we hold more on our balance sheet. In addition, there was the absence of $30 million in quarterly revenue from the Q3 sale of a small noncore appraisal business. 
Expenses declined 2% from Q4 '14 as the savings from reductions in financial centers and personnel more than offset our cost from investment in presale specialists. The cost of operating a deposit franchise remains low at 177 basis points. Operating leverage growth improvement in the efficiency ratio to 56% as we continued to experience shifts in customer activity away from branches towards self-serve options.
Mobile banking users increased to 18.7 million, which is up 13% from Q4 '14, and deposit transactions from these devices now represent 15% of deposit transactions. 
Slide 14 presents consumers' progress across a number of customer activities. I would highlight activities in 3 areas, loans, deposits and brokerage assets, where we continued to grow responsibly. These 3 products are the core of our rewards programs, where we share benefits with customers who deepen relationships with us. Average loans grew $12 billion from Q4 '14 in mortgages and vehicle lending. And in deposits, growth was strong at $48 billion or 9% from Q4, while the rate paid declined to 4 basis points.
Regarding brokerage assets. Merrill Edge asset levels of $123 billion are up 8% from last year even with declines in equity markets this year. 
Total mortgage production was up 13% from Q4 last year and stable with Q3. 
Looking at card activity, which includes GWIM, card issuance was strong at 1.3 million. Average U.S. card balances of $83 billion -- of $89 billion were down modestly from last year but up seasonally from Q3 '15.
U.S. cards' credit quality was strong as net charge-offs remain at deputy [ph] low levels of 2.5% with a risk-adjusted margin of 9.4%. Credit spending volumes finished on a high note as Q4 spending was 5% higher than last year, outpacing what we believe to be total market spend levels. Debit spending was strong as well. For example, on Christmas Eve day, we saw record debit card spending of more than $1 billion. 
In our consumer segment, we expect technology adoption by customers to continue to be a cornerstone of not only improved customer satisfaction but also efficiency gains and operating leverage. The latest examples of this are around digital selling and appointment setting. Digital sales in the fourth quarter were up more than 31% from last year. Digital appointments reached more than 16,000 in the recent week. We expect these adoption trends to play an increasing role in future performance and customer satisfaction as we continue to advance online and mobile capabilities. 
Turning to Slide 15. Global Wealth and Investment Management produced earnings of $614 million. Results were down from Q4 last year, driven by lower transactional revenue and the impact of the market decline on asset management fees. Transactional revenue continues to be impacted by the shifting of activity from brokerage to managed relationships as well as market uncertainty.
NII benefited from solid loan growth and solid deposit growth but was offset by the company's ALM activities, leaving NII relatively flat with Q4 '14. Noninterest expense was modestly higher than the year-ago period. Investment in client-facing professionals continues, while lower revenue caused decline in incentive compensation that was more than offset by amortization of stock awards issued in prior periods. Pretax margin was 21%, down from Q4 '14.
Beginning in the first quarter of 2016, we will benefit from lower expense resulting from the completion of amortizations related to advisory retention awards given at the time of the Merrill Lynch merger. 
Moving to Slide 16. Despite the volatility in market levels, we continue to see solid client activity, and we continue to invest in the business, growing wealth advisers 5% from Q4 last year. Long-term AUM flows were $7 billion and remained positive for the 26th consecutive quarter. Deposit flows were strong, growing end-of-balance -- growing end-of-period balances $15 billion from Q3. By the way, this may have been driven in part by client concerns with market volatility.
Loans continued to grow, improving 10% from last year. This is the 23rd consecutive quarter of average loan growth in this segment.
Turning to Slide 17. Global Banking earned $1.4 billion, down 9% from Q4 '14 but still generating a 16% return on allocated capital. The earnings decline from Q4 was driven by higher provision expense. Provision expense was up $264 million from Q4 last year, driven by higher energy-related charge-offs and reserve builds for loan growth and energy-related risks. Revenue increased modestly from Q4 '14 while expense declined modestly. 
Driven by higher loan balances, NII improved despite spread compression and the allocation of the company's ALM activities, including higher liquidity costs. Noninterest income benefited from higher treasury services revenue, higher leasing revenue and a small gain from the sale of its foreclosed property, partially offset by lower IB fees.
Looking at trends on Slide 18 and comparing to Q4 '14, IB fees of $1.3 billion were down 17% as leveraged finance and equity issuance was partially offset by advisory fees that were at second highest level since the Merrill merger. From a market share perspective, we maintained our #3 global fee ranking. 
Looking at the balance sheet, loans on average were $320 billion, up 12% year-over-year. The growth was broad based across C&I, real estate and leasing. We continue to experience some spread compression, although it has moderated relative to a year ago.
Asset quality of new loans was consistent with the overall portfolio. On deposits, we saw good performance with average deposits increasing by $16 billion or 5% over Q4 '14. The mix of these deposits remains very good with less than 5% classified as 100% run-off balances.
Switching to Global Markets on Slide 19 and compared to Q4 last year. We are pleased with the results here given challenging market conditions as the teams increased revenues while using lower asset levels and less VaR. Global Markets earned approximately $200 million. But we think when you consider results excluding DVA, on that basis, adjusted earnings were $308 million, which was relatively flat to Q4 '14 on a similarly adjusted basis.  Note that our net DVA loss this quarter was $198 million and compared to a loss of $626 million in Q4 '14, which included an initial FVA adjustment. Total revenue, excluding DVA, improved $313 million or 10% from the fourth quarter last year on improved FICC sales and trading. Outside of sales and trading, Global Markets' share of lower investment banking fees was offset by a gain on the sale of an equity investment. 
Noninterest expense increased 9%, in line with revenue improvement. 
Moving to trends on the next slide and focusing on the components of our sales and trading performance. Sales and trading revenue of $2.6 billion, excluding net DVA, was up 11.5% from Q4 '14. Compared to Q4 last year, FICC sales and trading of $1.8 billion improved 20%, reflecting improvements across most products, notably in rates and credit-related products. Equity trading of $822 million declined 3%, reflecting lower client activity. Average traded -- trading-related asset levels were down 9% in Q4 '14 while VaR was down 14%. 
Turning to Legacy Assets and Servicing on Slide 21. This segment lost roughly $350 million, in line with the prior year. Focus areas here are mortgage banking income, the number of delinquent loans and expenses, all compared to Q4 '14. First, mortgage banking income, which improved slightly, was driven by 3 factors. Rep and warranty provisioning improved $237 million to a provision of $9 million this quarter. That favorability was offset by a decline in servicing fees of $108 million as used service declined, as well as a decline in net MSR hedge performance of $152 million. Next, the number of first mortgage loans that we serviced that are 60 days delinquent continued to decline and are now at 103,000 units. And last, the team did an excellent job lowering expenses. Excluding litigation, we achieved our goal of $800 million, moving costs down $309 million or 28%.
On Slide 22, we show All Other, which reported a loss of $289 million. This was an improvement of $86 million from Q4 '14. This loss was driven by the $612 million pretax charge associated with our trust preferred as well as the impact on the U.K. tax law changes.  This was partially offset by gains on debt security sales as well as reserve releases on consumer real estate loans booked in All Other. 
A comment or 2 on taxes before wrapping up. The company's effective tax rate for the quarter, excluding the U.K. tax charge, was 25%, reflecting reoccurring tax benefits plus a few small [indiscernible] benefits. We would expect the tax rate to be in the low 30s for 2016, excluding unusual items. 
Before closing, I want to cover our early adoption of DVA accounting in more detail. In January of this year, the Financial Accounting Standards Board issued an update to allow early adoption of a new rule regarding recognition of DVA on financial liabilities from changes in our own credit spreads. The update means that these types of debit valuation adjustments will now flow through OCI instead of the income statement. We believe this change makes our earnings comparisons more meaningful and easier to understand. Therefore, we adopted early. We restated all prior years -- we, excuse me, restated all periods this year per the FASB rules, and those numbers are contained in the supplemental package.  This had no impact on capital as it moved dollars between retained earnings and OCI, but it did impact revenue, earnings, taxes and EPS in the first 3 quarters of 2015. The changes reduced previously reported EPS by approximately $0.02 each in Q1, Q2 and Q3. This accounting standard adoption did not impact DVA on derivatives, which continued to flow through trading account profits. 
Okay, let me conclude by offering a few takeaways. Although the U.S. economy is improving slowly, revenue growth remains challenging. This quarter, we continued our progress on those things we can control and drive. These include delivery for clients and customers within our risk framework and driving client and customer activity that will result in sustainable profits and returns. Our results reflect this focus. We maintain a strong foundation of capital and liquidity. We grew loans, deposits and investment flows. We continue to invest in our franchise by adding sales professionals and improved technology. Our strength, global capability and experience allowed us to deliver for clients in a challenging market environment. And we did all this while closely managing expenses.
With that, we'll open it up to Q&A.

componenttext: Sure. We'll look at this -- as we said in the comments, we've got reserves against that energy portfolio of $500 million. That's 6% of the high-risk subsectors. And when we develop reserves on an incurred basis, we develop them by looking at loss getting into default, probably to loss, exposure default. We go loan by loan. componenttext: I think to give additional color, if you think about it, if you go back a couple of years, we grew the international business because we had to round out that franchise. We sort of slowed that down 24 months ago. That's started to drop in terms of growth rate. And so because with the client structure criteria there, it's very high level -- very high in clients, multinational clients, et cetera. But we slowed it down just to keep the company in balance, and that's been our watchword. If you think about the consumer, those sub-prime, no more than FICO scores, if you look at the coming on FICOs are higher than the portfolio still, which is almost hard to believe, the charge-offs, delinquencies. And both home equities delinquencies across the last 4 years has continue to come -- get lower every year and this year was the lowest they've been, all the way back a long time in both the credit card and home equities. And if you look at the client structure in the U.S., a couple of things. One is, we're adding officers in the middle-market business, but they're going after our target clients. And this is not go find new industries, et cetera. So whether it's the way we lend in commercial real estate, which is down -- which is very high-end real estate developers, et cetera. The way we lend in middle-market is very strong. So if you look across this client selection in the middle-market business, it's been strong. But that's -- that we're seeing is things in our business banking, small business portfolio, we're actually starting to see growth there against sticky target credit risk, which is the first time in many years that we had to run off some stuff that came in through Postale [ph], Merrill and everything else that we're finally seeing nominal growth. And so I think it's client selection. We slowed down international. It's sort of always watching, and in fact, using your stress test to make sure you stay balanced. And if you look at us, we feel we're pretty balanced between the consumer and commercial, sort of 50-50. And then within the consumer, we're really staying to -- sticking to our knitting, which is very strong, high quality [indiscernible] creditworthy borrowers.

componenttext: It's coming from both. But the reality is that the #1 issue they face in the wealth investment broker services revenue line is the decline in transactional revenue. And it has gone from 2 years to probably $600 million a quarter, even in not robust market times, down to, I don't know, $300 million or $400 million a quarter. And that is hard to make up for the annuity streams. So even if they have record net flows, it's just that the pace -- the revenue rate on that is less. And so that's the factor. So it's not to do with really recruiting, and the production for FA continues to be solid at $1 million-plus [ph]. It's really that core fundamental issue that they are facing. And that transition is what we're all going through. It's getting, given the point where it's becoming less material and i.e., less material to the total revenue line from the transaction side.

componenttext: I think the one thing overall is that as you look at the question on this exposure that we're also paying close attention to is it sort of a demand or a supply issue for oil prices. And if it's a supply issue, that affects these companies and related companies and demand from. But if it's a demand in the broadest context, our economies continue to slow down, and that's the broader concern. So we're looking at not only the impact in all the portfolios, thinking about who gets the benefits in our portfolio basis from low energy costs, which are serious benefits to the consumers and to companies that consume energy, versus those producing it. And so there's a balance here that we've got to think through. Right now, it's pretty isolated -- the energy companies, and even if you look at consumers who work for them in our bases by ZIP code and unemployment levels and stuff, we've seen relatively modest deterioration or none, and in the consumer side, people employed in these businesses. So I think as you think about it, the real question is going to come down to for '16 in terms of all our industries, are we in a demand-driven issue, i.e., a general economic issue, or is the United States is going to plug along. And if it does, then I think follow-up guidance is the right one. If you're in the supply, it's going to all be localized on these industries.

headline: Bank of America Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, look, it's not demand. It's again worth emphasizing. There are a lot of people who are helped by low oil prices. That helps our asset quality, not only on the consumer side, but also in places like India and manufacturers that are all around
componenttext: Yes. I mean, look, it's not demand. It's again worth emphasizing. There are a lot of people who are helped by low oil prices. That helps our asset quality, not only on the consumer side, but also in places like India and manufacturers that are all around the world.

componenttext: The only other thing I would add is we still have some opportunities to optimize RWA from an advanced perspective. That's in 2 fundamental areas. There's always stuff you can do in markets and other areas, but on 2 fundamental areas. One is, the extra RWA we got on the wholesale side when we exited parallel run, that's not a permanent thing, we need to work on our models, work with our regulators. And hopefully over time, we can make some improvements there. The other one is operational risk. We have $500 billion of RWA for operational risk some of the advanced approach. That is 25% more than the next highest bank. And that operational risk is for businesses that we are no longer in, for products we no longer sell. It's for a risk profile that we no longer tolerate. So again, that will take time, but that's another opportunity for us to lower RWA from an advanced perspective.

componenttext: Well, let me take the last one first. So we've got a reserve on our energy portfolio of $500 million. That is 6% of those 2 subsectors that we think are high risk. And we have done modeling -- stress test modeling at various oil prices. The one we've been talking about on this call has been at $30, and that's over 9 quarters. And so if oil stayed at $30 for 9 quarters, we would think that our losses over those 9 quarters would be $700 million. Again, that would go against the $500 million we already have reserved and one we'd presume we'd be building reserves from that [indiscernible] to make up the difference.

componenttext: So Mike, when you look at consumer benefits from the oil and gas, just to give you simple things, if you look at our card base, in the fourth quarter of '15, the spending on debit and credit cards rose 4% from the fourth quarter of '14. If you translate that to dollars, the round number is at $20 million today less spending on gasoline by our consumers and our portfolios per day and from like $90 million down to $70-ish million or something like that. That is the benefit they get. And so for a large over consumers medium income, look, the cash flow increases, and that gives them more money to spend.

Before I turn the call over to Brian and Paul, let me remind you we may make some forward-looking statements.
